items.text: üëÄüëÄ

Two months ago, I hit "apply" for Google's TPU Research Cloud. Heart racing. No real plan. Just a hunch this could spark something big.

"Trust the process," I whispered to myself.

Everybody in the market kept hammering: "Find product-market fit. Solve a real problem."

I tried. Poked around ideas. Chased leads. But nothing clicked. Couldn't force it.
So I accepted it. Let go. Started hunting bigger: Problems plaguing humanity. Ones where throwing compute could yield massive energy gains.

Complex optimizations. Boosting efficiency in fundamental infrastructure. Like the electric grid‚Äîour crumbling backbone.

Blackouts in Spain. Congestion in California. Wasted renewables in India and Latin America. Ancient systems buckling under climate chaos, EVs, data centers, wild weather.

This felt right. Not just a gig‚Äîinnovation and progress. Still in my phase of discovering what I truly love doing.

Dug into AI-native solutions. Think Google Maps for electricity. Real-time predictions. Smarter balancing. Disaster prevention.

Shoutout to PravƒÅh's founders Dhruv Suri, Mohak Mangal, and Aman Gupta. Pilots in three countries. $1M funding. Using transformers, GNNs, RL agents to unlock millions in value and speed clean energy.

Spark ignited. Applied‚Äîand got in! 64 TPU v5e chips here, 64 v6e there, across zones. Compute jackpot.

Aiming it at Texas. ERCOT's chaos‚ÄîWinter Storm Uri failures, booming renewables, population boom.

Simulate probabilistic models. Train weather diffusion. Run RL for congestion games.

Preempt blackouts? Integrate solar without waste? Build resilience? Massive energy wins.

Things work out in wild ways. If you trust the process.

Not "The Summer I Turned Pretty"... but "The Summer I Trusted the Compute."
Part 1 of grid-hacking adventures. More soon :) Sharing the implementation guide here for those who are interested. 
https://lnkd.in/grrUR3PR

Thoughts? Ideas on big compute-for-good problems, TPU hacks, or infrastructure optimizations? If you're chasing innovation too‚Äîlet's chat!

"How to Scale Your Model" might be the best free resource if you want to work in the AI Scaling/ Hardware Industry. 

Released by the authors of Google DeepMind, it covers the math, systems and scaling laws for LLM training and inference workloads.

It's approachable yet thorough, an absolute must-read. It has got me into understanding basic JAX concepts and code. 

Full book here: https://lnkd.in/g8-pxkuY

This weekend, I developed QuantaFold, a tool designed to make amino acid sequence detection accessible to everyone. I fine-tuned a lightweight pLM (ESM-2 released by Meta AI labs) model to classify proteins into functional families.

My first model quickly achieved¬†97.9% accuracy¬†on the 1,000 most common protein families. However, it struggled with rarer, out-of-distribution examples. To address this, I engineered a training pipeline, curating a 400k-sample dataset and implementing a weighted loss function to manage the severe class imbalance. The resulting model trained for 4+ hours achieved¬†60% accuracy¬†on a much more difficult 5,000-class problem, demonstrating the viability of this advanced technique on real-world scientific data. 

This project reaffirmed a key insight:¬†the main bottleneck for many researchers and drug discovers isn't predicting perfect 3D structures, but rapidly getting a "good enough" functional clue to guide their work.¬†Lightweight, function-focused models can solve this by providing instant, accessible insights.
Here are the results:
https://lnkd.in/gwRG779U
https://lnkd.in/g8id5kiE
https://lnkd.in/gtwvz3ge
https://lnkd.in/gwnEAEgx

I fine-tuned a Gemma 1B model to help researchers improve their grant proposals. It rewrites rough drafts for clarity, impact, and adherence to specific NIH conventions.

I built: 
- Custom Data Pipelines:¬†Programmatically sourced 2,000+ funded abstracts from the NIH RePORTER API. 
Synthetic Data Generation:¬†Used a multi-model LLM router and 4 distinct "editor personas" to create a dataset of 1,808 (unoptimized, optimized) training pairs. 
Efficient Fine-Tuning:¬†Used LoRA (PEFT) with Keras 3 and the JAX backend to train on a single A100 GPU. 
Live & Interactive:¬†Deployed a working Gradio demo on Hugging Face for anyone to use.

Check out the full technical write-up and the live model below!
Live Demo: https://lnkd.in/gPZTBCuR

A Note on Performance:¬†The demo is running on free-tier CPU hardware, so inference can be slow (sometimes up to 3 minutes).

I spent a week in SF and it was insanely rewarding. Got to attend the biggest Gen AI summit of 2025, thanks to Melinda Villagran, PhD, also got to attend an amazing AI event at Snowflake HQ, got to visit the Salesforce tower thanks to Devansh Sharma and attend Replit x Apple's engineering day which was great. 

A big thanks to Akshay Shah, for inspiring me to always keep learning and growing in AI, to Anusha Dudi for the insightful talk and breaking down a career in AI for me, Jensen Coonradt for being the absolute greatest programming mind ever, and also David Ongchoco for the connections in the Comma event.

The one-day event was such a blast. Would love to see more of these events on campus. Thank you Tahir Ekin and Texas State University Center for Analytics and Data Science (TXST CADS) for organizing this and involving us students. 

On a different note: Students can get 1 year of Google One at this link using their TXST email. This includes Gemini, NotebookLM plus and Google's video generation model (soon).

These past few weeks have been the most engaging and intense of my life. From talking to over 100 people at SXSW while running on just 3 hours of sleep, to attending the Teaching and Learning Symposium, nothing failed to surprise me. I don‚Äôt think my body could have handled all this socializing if not for the amazing people I met during these events.

Here are a few notable ones:
1. Matthew Hall, CISSP, CHFI - A really fun guy with such a strong handshake. Thank you for bringing AI to TXST and making the AI Symposium possible, and for letting ACM AI @ TXST host demo tables there. I can‚Äôt skip mentioning Texas State University Center for Analytics and Data Science (TXST CADS), Dr. Tahir Ekin, and Christi Moncrief while on the topic of the AI Symposium. Also, a shoutout to Ms. Kimberly Conner, JD, for planning everything at the event, and Ryan Lara for teaching me so much about cloud computing.

2. Aimee Kendall Roundtree - The person with the strongest energy ever. I had the chance to demo my Find&Fund project to her and received incredible feedback, uncovering blind spots I wouldn‚Äôt have considered otherwise.

3. Harshal Bhatia - Bhaiya, literally the smartest and most strategic guy ever. I learned the most amazing things from him and am so grateful I met you while volunteering.

4. dr. nitin bajaj - Lowkey the most approachable guy in the world. Thank you for bringing the South Asian community together with the American South Asian Network (ASAN). This is an incredible initiative, and I‚Äôd love to get involved in more of your events.

5. Dr. Veronica Perez - Her research project on LLM persuasion is top-notch, and she‚Äôs one of the most cutting-edge researchers in the AI field at TXST.

And all the other amazing people I met during these events. It wouldn‚Äôt be possible to name all the 100+ people I talked to while volunteering at SXSW, but it was a once-in-a-lifetime experience, and Austin has officially stolen my heart at this point.

Was so tired after 27 hours but definitely worth it.

A big thanks to : 
- Michael Daigler: For coordinating everything, the fruits during the hackathon and for the motivating talk at 4am.
- Hardik Shah: For guiding our whole team throughout the process and teaching us the tips and tricks behind the amazing technology that is llama stack.

Great meeting everybody yesterday. Such great conversations with such great people. Made me wanna do more AI talks on campus. 

Thank you to the speakers and my team members for pulling this show on in such a small timeframe. We are representing the students demands on this topic.

üí• First Place at TXST Open Datathon!

Moments of controlled chaos has led to this LinkedIn post!
There were so many moments when I almost didn't attend this year's TXST Open Datathon; prior commitments, deadlines, and mismatched teams almost derailed our participation. But against all odds, my team (Kusum Bhattarai Sharma, Raghav Ojha, BETHIREDDY AJAY) not only participated but clinched the first place award at an event where over 24 teams presented! Even during our pitch, my voice was shaking and imposter syndrome was in full swing - but we did it! üöÄ 

So, what did we create? Something that hits close to home: we tackled the pressing issue of parking at Texas State University. Our team identified three optimal spots for new parking facilities on campus, based on a DESIRABILITY score computed with our Machine Learning models. 

We developed an algorithm for optimizing parking efficiency and vehicle allocation for new students.

We presented our findings in the Mixed group, competing with both undergrad and grad students, and emerged victorious! 

A massive thank you to my incredible team members:

Our project was backed by solid research, ensuring top-notch data accuracy.

Check out the demo app on Streamlit to see these things in action! 

Special thanks to:

Pranesh Aswath: For the great keynote and insightful discussion on how we students should spend our time and focus.
G. Marc Turner: For the amazing keynote, offering to help us get the data, vouching for us, and teaching us so much about data literacy.
Kevin Garza: For judging our project, asking insightful questions, and helping refine our work.
Jennifer Gross: For inspiring me with your Linux phone and your offer to help with the scholarship project.
Tahir Ekin and Texas State University Center for Analytics and Data Science (TXST CADS): For your continued support.
Xuan Zhou: For making the whole event smooth and possible.

And last but not least, a huge thanks to the library staff for helping with the event.

Sometimes, the best projects come from our own struggles. Here's to all the students who pull all-nighters for a datathon!  

https://lnkd.in/gq-6rerA

#AI #Education #Innovation #winner #TXST #ML

Researchers know the pain of hunting for funding - but it's not because there isn't enough money out there. The real issue is an ASYMMETRIC DATA PROBLEM: too many opportunities with vague descriptions.

I've scraped over 40,000 grants, SBIRs, and funding opportunities from NSF, grants.gov, NIF to prove that funding exists; it's just hard to find. That's why I've built https://lnkd.in/g-HHNbPb. Here's how it works:

Personalized Matching: We pull your research profile from OpenAlex, create a tailored researcher profile, and match it with grants that align with your work.
Precision Over Quantity: Instead of overwhelming you with options, we provide 5 highly relevant grants using cosine similarity between profile embedding and grants embeddings, keyword overlap and some LLM magic .

This is just v1, but I'm excited to see how it can evolve with your feedback. Custom recommendations will need more compute, but I believe it's doable.

Try it out here: https://lnkd.in/g-HHNbPb and tell us how it changes your grant hunting experience or share with a colleague who's struggling to match their research with funding.

Check out my code for frontend here: https://lnkd.in/gP4h_q3K
Code for recommendation system here: https://lnkd.in/gD8KY8bv

#ResearchFunding #AcademicGrants #InnovationInResearch Ingram School of Engineering McCoy College of Business at Texas State University

I recently built an MCP which lets Anthropic's Claude fetch grants data from grants.gov. 

Some key features:
- Search for grants by keyword
- Paginate the search results
- Display detailed info on each grant, including funding details, deadlines, and eligibility

Check out the code here: https://lnkd.in/gfxYpaD8

Let me know if you have any questions or feedback! Happy to discuss further.
#opensource #mcp #grants #govtech #llm

Just launched the v1 of obvius.site!

Update: The app semi-blew up on X and Tiktok and got close to 6.8k people who got recommended a place. This got my API bill up a lot but was worth it. 

Obvius uses Google DeepMind's Gemini 2.0 Model and Google Maps Street View's API to help you find unique places. It's like having a personal travel explorer right in your pocket.

'Obvius' in Latin relates to 'coming across' or 'finding'. This app helps you encounter unique places you might not discover on your own. Check it out and tell me what you think:  https://obvius.site/

We've all heard AI companies touting promises of world-changing research, yet tangible results often feel just out of reach. I thought well if big AI companies won't build something I will. 

Over the past week, I took on the challenge of building the same AI research application using two different approaches:

1Ô∏è‚É£ From Scratch with Code: I developed a simple Streamlit frontend with a complex architecture based on the Mixture of Agents architecture‚Äîimagine a team of LLMs similar to ChatGPT, each with a specific role, working together harmoniously. This was built from the ground up using Groq and the impressive Perplexity API. Crafting this was both intense and incredibly rewarding.

2Ô∏è‚É£ The No-Code Route: I recreated the app using Langflow on DataStax. While there was a learning curve (yes, even with no-code!), once overcome, it was astounding how much could be achieved without traditional coding. For visual thinkers like myself, no-code platforms can unlock creativity in ways that conventional coding doesn't. It almost made coding feel... hard! üòÖ

 The Takeaway: Both approaches have their merits. Coding offers deep customization, while no-code platforms provide accessibility and speed ( I was able to spin up a prototype in 3 hours). 

 Check out the Streamlit app here: https://lnkd.in/gG8EYJYc

I'd love to hear your thoughts on coding vs. no-code in AI development. Which do you prefer, and why?

I‚Äôm always amazed by how much impact a small group of students can have!

As part of Hackacat Nano at Texas State University, we developed a solution to enhance Bobcat Bounty, a student-run food pantry that addresses food insecurity on campus. This helps to carry forward the idea of global, national, state, local, and institutional food security, and explores novel technological solutions to those problems

The Challenge:
Users struggled with knowing the real-time inventory of available items, often leading to unnecessary trips to the pantry, only to find certain items out of stock.

Our Solution (Built in just 7 hours!):
‚úÖ A web app and smartphone app that display a real-time inventory of available food items, complete with dietary details (e.g., gluten-free, vegetarian).
‚úÖ AI chatbot for question answering and AI-generated recipe suggestions to inspire users to make the most of pantry items.
‚úÖ User-enabled updates to inventory, ensuring accurate stock information for others.

Technologies Used:
Frontend: React
Backend: Postgres Neon
Design: Figma prototype
Hosting: Replit

I‚Äôm incredibly proud of what our team made up of Kusum Bhattarai Sharma, BETHIREDDY AJAY, Ella Maldonado, Sri Naga Sri Govvala, Fidel Loza, Stephanie Valderrama accomplished in such a short time, combining creativity, collaboration, and technical skills to deliver a meaningful solution.

A big thank you to Bobcat Bounty for inspiring us, the HACKACAT organizers Mason Melead, Kailey Couillard and Frank Jones for this opportunity, and my amazing teammates for making this possible. 

It was a pleasure to also connect with Jayneba Dieye after the hackathon and get some feedback about our project. 

You can check out the web app here: 
https://lnkd.in/gXQ_ymsY

GIthub code: 
https://lnkd.in/gFwUC39n
https://lnkd.in/gZyhNWhK

I scraped the universities course catalog information and put it in a vector database to be queried by a LLM model. A big thanks to Christian Reetz for the idea and his code on the same topic.

Austin Tech Week came to a close yesterday, marking the end of an incredible event. I got to attend the Startup Crawl at the Capital Factory  alongside fellow members of the ACM AI @ TXST club, and it was a refreshing experience. It was great to connect with several innovative AI startups and gain insights directly from their founders.

Thank you Mason Melead for making this possible and also Texas State University Center for Analytics and Data Science (TXST CADS), for the tickets. 

I had the privilege of connecting with an inspiring group of individuals, including Chad Chadwell, Syed Moiz, Idrees Madni, Dylan Wu, among others. 

A great way to end off a productive week.

How we created an ‚Äúintimate‚Äù social media experience in 24 hours of hacking. 

This weekend I had the opportunity to attend UTSA RowdyHacks along with Mason Melead, Maria Renee San Esteban  and Jonathan Davis. 

We came up with the idea of a digital time capsule called ‚ÄúEchoz‚Äù.

Our Geo-based time capsule allows everyone to share, view, and find echoes of the past while leaving more for the future.

Built with React-native GitHub, Amazon Web Services (AWS)-s3, Groq  and a desire to learn more!

We had a blast coming up with the concept and putting together a product we were all proud of. I am surprised how much we get done in the span of 24 hours during hackathons. 

A big thanks to Christian Reetz, Nilanjan Chatterjee and the other mentors for all the support they provided along the way. 

Also, a notable mention to all the organizers and staff that made the event possible. 

If you want to know more about how we built it dm me. 

#hackathons #rowdyhacks
